references: In this section, a classic 3-tier multi-agent edge computing system will be firstly introduced, including the corresponding communication and operation models. Then, the problems concerned in age sensitive scenarios will be defined.
, a classic 3-tier edge computing system with data collection is studied. The bottom level are data sources (
) such as sensors, web cameras and usersâ€™ equipments that continuously generate data packets. Then middle level consists of mobile edge devices (

) such as automobile base stations and unmanned aerial vehicle base stations (UAV-BSs) which manage to move in the area, communicate with the data sources and the cloud center, as well as carry out some processing of the data. At the top level, the cloud center (

) is usually the data center with computing clusters that execute the computing tasks, store the data and implement centralized control for the whole system. The related models of data generation, edge mobility, edge operation, data scheduling, transmission and center controller will be introduced in detail. Additionally, some necessary notations and their explanations are listed in TABLEÂ
. To explicitly investigate the operations in each time slot, we divide continuous time into small slots and use the integer

references: Secondly, let us claim some basic environment settings of simulations. The main parameter settings are listed in Table II. As for data sources, we set the arrival probability and the generating rate as 0.30.30.3 and 111Kb/slot. Then, for the attributes of edge devices, we set rmâ€‹oâ€‹vâ€‹eksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘£ğ‘’r^{k}_{move}, roâ€‹bâ€‹sksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ r^{k}_{obs}, rcâ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹lâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹tksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡r^{k}_{collect} to be 666, 606060, 404040 in measure of the grid map and the height is fixed. The computing rate of edge process is 202020Kb/slot and the maximum buffer lengths for caching collected data and executed data are both set to be 555 packet pieces. For edge-cloud communication channel, we set the total offloading bandwidth as 100100100MHz, the carrier frequency fğ‘“f in Eq.(2.8) as 2.52.52.5GHz, the noise power spectral density N0subscriptğ‘0N_{0} as âˆ’130130-130dB, and the max transmission power Ptâ€‹r,mâ€‹aâ€‹xksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥P^{k}_{tr,max} as 0.20.20.2W. The coefficients (a,b,Î·Lâ€‹oâ€‹S,Î·Nâ€‹Lâ€‹oâ€‹S)ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ‘œğ‘†subscriptğœ‚ğ‘ğ¿ğ‘œğ‘†(a,b,\eta_{LoS},\eta_{NLoS}) in Eq.(2.8) and Eq.(2.10) are selected to be (9.61,0.16,1,20)9.610.16120(9.61,0.16,1,20), which refers to the urban scenarios mentioned in [47]. Particularly, the transmission rate of edge-source collection is fixed to be 888Kb/slot due to the limit of collection cover.

S5.T3.caption: TABLE III: A numerical comparison on AoI metrics.
S5.T3.table:
Approach Average age Î”Â¯â€‹(t)Â¯Î”ğ‘¡\overline{\Delta}(t) Peak AoI
mean std peak count Î”Â¯psubscriptÂ¯Î”ğ‘\overline{\Delta}_{p} vâ€‹aâ€‹râ€‹(Î”p)ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘ŸsubscriptÎ”ğ‘var(\Delta_{p})
Mixed DDPG 473.3 174.4 10121 26.6 156.0
Mixed MADDPG 39.3 16.7 12842 24.9 93.0
EdgeFed H-MAAC (proposed) 21.2 3.6 13782 21.7 23.1
references: Fig. 5 and Table III show the comparison results of proposed algorithm (set Ï‰=0.5ğœ”0.5\omega=0.5) and the baselines under the environment with 4 edge devices and 30 data sources on a 200Ã—200200200200\times 200 map where the positions of edge devices and data sources are initialized randomly. The average age Î”Â¯â€‹(t)Â¯Î”ğ‘¡\overline{\Delta}(t) during the online interaction is shown in Fig. 5(a) where one can find that the mixed DDPG results in highest Î”Â¯â€‹(t)Â¯Î”ğ‘¡\overline{\Delta}(t) and the curve is not stable till 5K epoch. However, under mixed MADDPG and EdgeFed H-MAAC, the average age maintains at a lower value after sufficient iterations. Specifically, the statistics of Î”Â¯â€‹(t)Â¯Î”ğ‘¡\overline{\Delta}(t) are listed in Table III. EdgeFed H-MAAC attains not only the lowest average age, but also the lowest variance, which means the edge-federated approach outperforms DDPG as well as MADDPG on both system penalty and learning stability. The right-hand part of Table III presents the comparison on PAoI. Evidently, the proposed collaboration algorithm reaps most peak updates and lowest average PAoI, Î”Â¯psubscriptÂ¯Î”ğ‘\overline{\Delta}_{p}. This implies that the efficiency of data processing in MEC can be promoted by EdgeFed H-MAAC. The lowest variance of PAoI also demonstrate that all data sources are updated frequently and fairly. Fig. 5(b) displays the worst AoI of three approaches. EdgeFed H-MAAC also performs the best. One can find that under the centralized DDPG, some sources are ignored for a long time. We explain this as the fact that the centralized collaboration algorithms require larger neural network models with complex structure to extract the relations between the excessive global input states and the local policies of each individual agent, which also leads to the difficulties for training. Besides, Fig. 5(c) and 5(d) present the volume and the count of the aggregated packets received at the cloud center, namely, the final hop of the MEC system. The curves illustrate that EdgeFed H-MAAC collaboration algorithm also improves the data utility of the MEC system by finishing more data processing within same time.
